article.Heading: Budget 2017: NDA’s Mission Antyodaya to lift 10 million out of poverty
article.Summary: “Over Rs 3 lakh crores are spent in rural areas every year, if we add up all the programmes meant for rural poor from the Central Budget, State Budgets, Bank linkage for self-help groups, etc,” Jaitley said in his budget speech.
article.Body:
Moneycontrol Bureau

Finance minister Arun Jaitley on Wednesday announced the introduction of the “Mission Antyodaya”-- an ambitious programme aimed at lifting 10 million families out of poverty.

“Over Rs 3 lakh crores are spent in rural areas every year, if we add up all the programmes meant for rural poor from the Central Budget, State Budgets, Bank linkage for self-help groups, etc,” Jaitley said in his budget speech.

“With a clear focus on improving accountability, outcomes and convergence, we will undertake a Mission Antyodaya to bring one crore households out of poverty and to make 50,000 gram panchayats poverty free by 2019, the 150th birth anniversary of Gandhiji,” he said.

The government, Jaitley said, will utilise the existing resources more effectively along with annual increases. This mission will work with a focused micro plan for sustainable livelihood for every deprived household.

A composite index for poverty free gram panchayats would be developed to monitor the progress from the baseline.

This will be done through addressing all the parameters of poverty and constantly measuring them on a scale of multiple indices based on data collated through the Socio-Economic Caste Census (SECC).

According to the SECC data, which was released in 2015, nearly one of three 180 families in India’s villages—or about 31.2 percent of the rural population—are poor with an income hardly enough to buy even the bare essentials.

The SECC analysis used an “exclusion-inclusion” method count the poor, different from the erstwhile Planning Commission’s consumption and calorie intake-based estimates.

The “Mission Antyodaya” push in Budget 2017 is aimed at offsetting demonetisation’s negative fallout in villages, while also addressing longer-term poverty alleviation issues.

The economy-wide drain out of the old Rs 500 and R1,000 notes have hurt many landless rural households. The cash-crunch had slowed down production forcing factories and construction companies to retrench semi-skilled and unskilled employees who have returned to villages in search of work.
